title: What Is a Lip Tie?
author: Katie Cameron

content: A lip tie is a condition where the skin of the upper lip is attached to the gums in a way that can limit lip movement and make breastfeeding difficult for your baby. Learn more about how lip ties are diagnosed and what your options are for fixing one if your baby is affected.
The exact cause of lip ties is unknown, but some experts think the condition runs in families. (Photo Credit: iStock/Getty Images)

content_blocks.text: A lip tie is a condition where the skin of the upper lip is attached to the gums in a way that can limit lip movement and make breastfeeding difficult for your baby. Learn more about how lip ties are diagnosed and what your options are for fixing one if your baby is affected.
The exact cause of lip ties is unknown, but some experts think the condition runs in families. (Photo Credit: iStock/Getty Images)

sections.heading: What Causes a Lip Tie?
content: Opinions differ on what causes lip ties. Some experts believe that the condition runs in families, meaning if you had or have a lip tie, your child might be more likely to have one. But the exact cause of lip ties is still unknown.

content_blocks.text: Opinions differ on what causes lip ties. Some experts believe that the condition runs in families, meaning if you had or have a lip tie, your child might be more likely to have one. But the exact cause of lip ties is still unknown.

sections.heading: How Are Lip Ties Diagnosed?
content: If you think your baby may have a lip tie, talk to a medical professional and have it checked out. You can talk to any of the following experts:
During the checkup, a medical professional will talk to you about breastfeeding and may ask to watch your baby feed so they can look for signs of a lip tie. They will check the following:

Medical experts will also check for the presence of a lip tie by looking underneath your baby’s upper lip. There are four levels of severity when diagnosing a lip tie, with level four being the most severe:
bullets: Your baby’s doctor
A lactation expert if you are breastfeeding
A dentist who specializes in correcting lip ties and tongue ties
Your baby’s ability (or inability) to latch deep enough for effective feeding
If your baby makes a clicking sound during breastfeeding, which is a sign of a poor latch
Spitting milk out or choking on milk
Feeding with high frequency, called cluster feeding
Poor weight gain or transfer of milk during a breastfeeding session
Development of jaundice , which is a condition where your baby’s skin turns slightly yellow
Level 1 – Mucosal
Level 2 – Gingival
Level 3 – Papillary
Level 4 – Papilla penetrating

sections.heading: How Does a Lip Tie Affect Breastfeeding?
content: Breastfeeding is natural, but that doesn’t mean it’s easy. Your nipples may be sore when breastfeeding your baby, but severe pain or damage to your nipples is a sign that something is wrong with your baby’s latch. You may experience:
bullets: Pain when your baby is nursing
Damage to your nipples
Changes in the shape of your nipples
Breast issues such as engorgement, blocked ducts, or mastitis
Issues with your milk supply, either too much or too little

sections.heading: Lip Tie Problems Later in Life
content: Lip ties can cause complications for your baby over time, including:
When a baby can’t breastfeed effectively, it can lead to poor nutrition. A severe lip tie may also affect your baby’s dental health. Lip ties often lead to tooth decay in children.

Lip ties can lead to tooth decay for your baby when milk and bits of food get trapped in the teeth because of the upper lip. It is important to clean the area behind your baby’s upper lip well to prevent this. If your baby’s teeth are not cleaned well in that area, your child may also experience a receding of their gums because of bacterial buildup.

content_blocks.text: Lip ties can cause complications for your baby over time, including:
When a baby can’t breastfeed effectively, it can lead to poor nutrition. A severe lip tie may also affect your baby’s dental health. Lip ties often lead to tooth decay in children.

Lip ties can lead to tooth decay for your baby when milk and bits of food get trapped in the teeth because of the upper lip. It is important to clean the area behind your baby’s upper lip well to prevent this. If your baby’s teeth are not cleaned well in that area, your child may also experience a receding of their gums because of bacterial buildup.

sections.heading: Diet issues
content: A lip tie can also cause a huge gap between the front two teeth. This happens when the lip tie is so severe that it extends beyond the gums and connects onto the palate of the roof of their mouth.

As your baby gets older, an untreated lip tie may lead to trouble eating some foods. For example, their lip may not be able to move enough to clean the food off of a spoon, or they may struggle to move bites of food with their lip for chewing. If this happens, your child may develop eating habits that seem picky.

content_blocks.text: A lip tie can also cause a huge gap between the front two teeth. This happens when the lip tie is so severe that it extends beyond the gums and connects onto the palate of the roof of their mouth.

As your baby gets older, an untreated lip tie may lead to trouble eating some foods. For example, their lip may not be able to move enough to clean the food off of a spoon, or they may struggle to move bites of food with their lip for chewing. If this happens, your child may develop eating habits that seem picky.

sections.heading: Lip Tie Procedure
content: The procedure for correcting a lip tie is called a frenectomy and is done by a dentist. Although it takes only a few minutes to complete, it is considered a surgery. Your baby will lie in a chair or on a table and will probably be strapped down to prevent sudden movements.

content_blocks.text: The procedure for correcting a lip tie is called a frenectomy and is done by a dentist. Although it takes only a few minutes to complete, it is considered a surgery. Your baby will lie in a chair or on a table and will probably be strapped down to prevent sudden movements.

content: The dentist will apply a numbing solution to your baby’s gums to prevent any discomfort. Then, they will use a small, handheld laser to cut the piece of skin connecting the lip to the gums.

Right after the procedure is finished, your baby is free to be held and breastfed if they want to. Some babies often experience an immediate improvement in latch, while others may need time to adjust. Depending on your baby’s age, they may take time to get a deeper latch during breastfeeding. They may have a habit of latching incorrectly and will need guidance to learn how to latch properly.

Keep in mind that you will have to complete stretches for your baby multiple times a day as your baby’s upper lip heals. By pulling up on the lip and gently rubbing the area with a clean finger, you can prevent the skin from growing back together.

sections.heading: Lip Tie FAQs
content: Does a lip tie cause gapped teeth?

content_blocks.text: Does a lip tie cause gapped teeth?

content: Some experts believe a lip tie can cause a child’s teeth to gap and that removing it may lower their odds of having gapped teeth when permanent teeth come in. Others believe more research is needed to prove that lip ties can cause dental issues.
What is the best age for a frenectomy?

There’s no exact right age for a frenectomy, or lip tie surgery. But if the lip tie is making it hard for your baby to feed or if your pediatrician is concerned that it may cause other issues later, many experts suggest having the surgery sooner rather than later. Other children may need one later if their vocal patterns are being affected by a lip tie.

sources: American Speech-Language-Hearing Association: “ Just Flip the Lip! The Upper Lip-tie and Feeding Challenges .”
La Leche League International: “ Tongue and Lip Ties. ”
Nia Pediatric Dentistry & Orthodontics: “What is a Lip Tie, and How Can My Child Be Treated for It?”
meta_description: A lip tie is when the upper lip is attached to the gums and prevents lip movement. Learn more about the signs of a lip tie and how it is corrected.
